subject: Clean up logical volume on resize/migrate
commit_message:
Clean up logical volume on resize/migrate

When resize/migrate VM, the logical volume on source host was not
deleted, this will cause some garbage logical volume on source host
if resize/migrate to different host.

In addition, if an instance is resized/migrated to a hypervisor with
a previous old logical volume (with that same instance disk ID) it
will simply re-use the existing volume and not upgrade/downgrade the
image size.

The fix was destroy the old logical volume when resize instance,
thus when resize finished, nova compute will try to re-create the
logical volume image again based on new flavor.

Change-Id: Ie967127c7e2611f42d6ed41143c0059767baccc1
Closes-Bug: #1241866

subject: Add support for testing VMware
commit_message:
Add support for testing VMware

The basic building blocks for testing VMware are put into place. To
support testing Openstack, the following changes are made:

- vmware test package: All vmware tests will placed in the
  "tempest.vmware.*" package. Packages and tests will follow similar
  naming conventions and hierarchies as laid out by the currently
  existing tests.

- vmware configuration section: A new configuration section, [vmware],
  will be added to tempest.conf. This section will provide options
  to set whether vmware tests should be run at all or not as well as
  control behavior in vmware-specific tests.

- vmware base test case class: All vmware tests will inherit from a
  base test case class that will provide API access to a vmware
  environment under test.

- vsphere api modules: The libraries used to communicate with vmware
  environments will be placed in the "tempest.vmware" package. The
  libraries are similar to those used in nova and cinder to talk with
  vmware hosts or vcenters.

- vmware test: A first test is created to demonstrate what a vmware
  test will look like. This test is a simple one that verifies that
  a server is spawned and exists on a vCenter

subject: Simplify callers of diskfile.[read|write]_metadata()
commit_message:
Simplify callers of diskfile.[read|write]_metadata()

As it happens, diskfile.read_metadata() and diskfile.write_metadata()
can take either an open file or a filename as their first arguments
(since xattr.[get|set]xattr() can), so we can clean up a couple places
where we were opening a file just to call read_metadata() or
write_metadata() on it. This results in 2 fewer system calls.

Example strace output:

/* read_metadata(filename) */
getxattr("/mnt/sdb1/1/node/sdb1/afile", "user.some.key", 0x0, 0) = 10
getxattr("/mnt/sdb1/1/node/sdb1/afile", "user.some.key", "some-value", 10) = 10

/* fp = open(filename); read_metadata(fp) */
open("/mnt/sdb1/1/node/sdb1/afile", O_RDONLY) = 4
fstat(4, {st_mode=S_IFREG|0664, st_size=0, ...}) = 0
fgetxattr(4, "user.some.key", 0x0, 0)   = 10
fgetxattr(4, "user.some.key", "some-value", 10) = 10

subject: Properly handle transport URL config on the client
commit_message:
Properly handle transport URL config on the client

On the client side, in the rabbit and qpid drivers, we use a connection
pool to avoid opening a connection for each message we send. However,
there is only currently one connection pool per process:

 def get_connection_pool(conf, connection_cls):
     with _pool_create_sem:
         # Make sure only one thread tries to create the connection pool.
         if not connection_cls.pool:
             connection_cls.pool = ConnectionPool(conf, connection_cls)
     return connection_cls.pool

This is a nasty artifact of the original RPC having no conectp of a
transport context - everything was a global. We'll fix this soon enough.

In the meantime, we need to make sure we only use this connection pool
where we're not using the default transport configuration from the
config file - i.e. where we supply a transport URL.

The use case here is cells - we send messages to a remote cell by
connecting to it using a transport URL. In our devstack testing, the
two cells are on the same Rabbit broker but under different virtual
hosts. Because we were always using the connection pool on the client
side, we were seeing both cells always send messages to the '/' virtual
host.

Note - avoiding the connection pool in the case of cells is the same
behaviour as the current RPC code:

 def cast_to_server(conf, context, server_params, topic, msg, connection_pool):
     ...
     with ConnectionContext(conf, connection_pool, pooled=False,
                            server_params=server_params) as conn:

subject: make libvirt driver get_connection thread-safe
commit_message:
make libvirt driver get_connection thread-safe

libvirt driver's get_connection is not thread safe in the
presence of a libvirtd restart during concurrent incoming
requests.

With existing code each will in turn call get_connection,
find the connection is broken, try to create new one, block
for a while and yield to the next thread to do the same.
You get as many connections as there are incoming requests
and only the last one is used finally. If enough are incoming
these connections can exhaust the client pool configured
for libvirtd.
One fix is to hold a lock while creating the connection.
Note that has_min_version calls _conn which calls get_connection
and thus the direct call to _has_min_version()

Also added the exception text if it fails to register an event
handler for lifecycle events.

Change-Id: I090765802bfe443440f16722bc7c43b6280fe56a
Fixes: bug #1240905
